</ul>
<h2><a id="post-129063-_odp1m3lxt5m2"></a><strong>Appendix</strong></h2>
<h3><a id="post-129063-_mya0jyex1fns"></a><strong>Technical Analysis of BMW Campaign</strong></h3>
<p>The hyperlinks found within the malicious <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">BMW 5 for sale in Kyiv - 2023.docx</span> flyers (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">311e9c8cf6d0b295074ffefaa9f277cb1f806343be262c59f88fbdf6fe242517</span> and (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">8902bd7d085397745e05883f05c08de87623cc15fe630b36ad3d208f01ef0596</span>) lead to a site (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://resetlocations[.]com/bmw.htm</span>) that was offline in mid-June, but they originally retrieved a large HTA file. (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">47e8f705febc94c832307dbf3e6d9c65164099230f4d438f7fe4851d701b580b</span>) This HTA file contains roughly 10 MB of Base64-encoded and XORed data, followed by JavaScript code.</p>
<p>The JavaScript code would first make a request to the same domain on the URI <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kll.php</span>, before decoding the embedded data mentioned above and triggering the browser to download it using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">msSaveOrOpenBlob</span>, or a mix of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">createElement</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">createObjectURL</span> should <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">msSaveOrOpenBlob</span> fail. The downloaded file is assigned the name <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bmw.iso</span> (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">79a1402bc77aa2702dc5dca660ca0d1bf08a2923e0a1018da70e7d7c31d9417f</span>), matching the theme seen thus far.</p>
<p>Once downloaded, execution is reliant on the user clicking the downloaded file, which mounts the disk image to the system and opens up Windows File Explorer. This reveals nine total files masquerading as images, which are instead LNK shortcut files (shown in the execution flow diagram in Figure 3).</p>
<p>A hidden folder named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">$Recycle.Bin</span> is created alongside the LNK files. This folder contains the real PNG images as well as three DLLs, an encrypted payload and a legitimate copy of Microsoft Word named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">windoc.exe</span>.</p>
<p>If one of the LNK files is clicked, the following command line is executed. Note that the image name is changed depending on the LNK file clicked:</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-129110" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129063-5-2.png" alt="Command line of the LNK file" width="800" height="49" /></p>
<p>While <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">windoc.exe</span> is not malicious, it does attempt to load several DLLs on runtime and falls victim to DLL hijacking. As a result, it will load two of the three DLLs within its current directory, namely <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">APPVISVSUBSYSTEMS64.dll</span> (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">38f8b8036ed2a0b5abb8fbf264ee6fd2b82dcd917f60d9f1d8f18d07c26b1534</span>) and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSVCP140.dll</span>. (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">706112ab72c5d770d89736012d48a78e1f7c643977874396c30908fa36f2fed7</span>). The third DLL (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Mso20Win32Client.dll</span>) does not appear to be essential to the malware’s functioning and is added so that <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">windoc.exe</span> runs correctly, similarly to the DLL described below.</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSVCP140</span> is not digitally signed, but does not contain any malicious functionality. It appears to only contain a select few exports from a legitimate copy of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSVCP140</span>. It’s likely that this was included to execute <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">windoc.exe</span> on systems that did not have Microsoft Visual C++ Redistributables – at least enough so that it would load <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">APPVISVSUBSYSTEMS64</span>.</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">APPVISVSUBSYSTEMS64</span>, on the other hand, is a fairly obfuscated DLL. It leverages a large number of unnecessary assembly instructions, including the following, likely hindering decompilation efforts and slowing down analysis:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Psllq</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Emms</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Pcmpeqd</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Punpckhbw</span></li>
</ul>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">APPVISVSUBSYSTEMS64</span> contains a number of anti-analysis techniques, including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Making sure its process name is set to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">windoc.exe</span></li>
<li>Checking that the system has more than one processor</li>
<li>Leveraging <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NtQueryObject</span> to search for any existing <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Debug Objects</span>, to check for the existence of a debugger</li>
</ul>
<p>If these checks are all passed, the sample will proceed to open the encrypted payload file found within the ISO file, in this case named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ojg2.px</span>. (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c62199ef9c2736d15255f5deaa663158a7bb3615ba9262eb67e3f4adada14111</span>). Once read into memory, it will decrypt the file using an XOR operation, which results in a secondary shellcode layer.</p>
<p>The shellcode is then injected into the first two active Windows processes that it can inject into, such as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">taskhost.exe</span> or <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sihost.exe</span>, using a technique that is somewhat similar to one previously used by Cloaked Ursa (as recently described by <a href="https://www.gov.pl/web/baza-wiedzy/espionage-campaign-linked-to-russian-intelligence-services">the Military Counterintelligence Service and CERT.PL</a>).</p>
<p>First, the shellcode is mapped and copied into the remote process using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NtMapViewOfSection</span> before a new remote thread is created in a suspended state using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NtCreateThreadEx</span>. The interesting aspect of this injection technique is that instead of the created thread pointing to the shellcode entry point or any Windows API, it is given a start address of a function within the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">APPVISVSUBSYSTEMS64</span> process. It’s possible that the authors did this to evade monitoring tools from identifying a newly created thread pointing to malicious shellcode.</p>
<p>Before the thread is resumed with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NtResumeThread</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">APPVISVSUBSYSTEMS64</span> will use <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NtGetContextThread</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NtSetContextThread</span> to modify the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RCX</span> register (which will contain the thread entry) to point to the entry point of the shellcode.</p>
<figure id="attachment_129114" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129114" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129114" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129063-6-2.png" alt="Image 5 is a screenshot of many lines of code. It starts with NTCreateThreadEx(. The creation of the thread points to a local function, resolves, API, and modifies the thread context." width="900" height="496" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129114" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Creation of thread pointing to a local function (resolves API) and modification of thread context.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This results in the resumed thread calling <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RtlUserThreadStart</span>, which will move the value in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RCX</span> register to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">R9</span> before calling it, thus triggering the shellcode.</p>
<p>The goal of the shellcode is to extract the final executable file payload in memory and transfer execution to it. This payload is the final sample in the infection chain and is responsible for handling communication to and from the command and control (C2) server.</p>
<p>The final payload contains a large array of obfuscation techniques, including string encryption and junk functions, as well as modifying exception handling structures to place “try and except” clauses part way through assembly instructions. This effectively breaks the instructions when disassembling, as many disassemblers will take these structure values into consideration when parsing a binary file. This results in a mangled control flow graph and failed decompilation due to the modifications in the <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/build/exception-handling-x64?view=msvc-160" target="_blank" rel="noopener">exception handling</a> structures.</p>
<p>For communication, the payload uses both the Microsoft Graph and Dropbox API. Cloaked Ursa has previously leveraged Dropbox as a C2 server. However, Cloaked Ursa’s use of Microsoft Graph API to facilitate C2 communications appears to be a relatively new addition to their toolkit.</p>
<p>In addition to the string encrypted tokens and API keys required to communicate with these platforms, there is another string that stands out (shown in Figure 6), used when communicating with the Microsoft Graph API: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Teams_test</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_129118" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129118" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129118" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129063-7-2.png" alt="Image 6 is a screenshot of a few strings. These are string decryption functions, used to decrypt core Dropbox and Microsoft Graph API information." width="900" height="92" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129118" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. String decryption functions used to decrypt core Dropbox and Microsoft Graph API information.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Given that the Graph API allows for interacting with a number of different Microsoft 365 Services including Microsoft Teams, it’s possible that this was an initial test for communicating via Teams or the Graph API.</p>
<p>If communication fails via the Graph API several times, communication via Dropbox is attempted. Several decrypted strings in the binary provide insight into the use of Dropbox for communication:</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-129122" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129063-8-2.png" alt="Decrypted strings in the binary that used the Dropbox API. There are eight in total. " width="600" height="181" /></p>
<p>Previously, Cloaked Ursa-linked <a href="https://github.com/Dump-GUY/Malware-analysis-and-Reverse-engineering/blob/main/APT29_C2-Client_Dropbox_Loader/APT29-DropboxLoader_analysis.md" target="_blank" rel="noopener">payloads that communicate with Dropbox</a> had wrapped communications in a packet that resembled an MP3 file. The MP3 magic bytes (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ID3\x04\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00#TSSE</span>) were prepended to the encrypted data and uploaded to Dropbox as an MP3 file.</p>
<p>In this sample, it appears that they have opted to use BMP files. The threat actor-owned C2 will upload commands to Dropbox that are wrapped in the BMP format. These commands are retrieved by the payload and then parsed, decrypted and executed. Any data that the payload uploads to Dropbox will also be encrypted and wrapped in the BMP format.</p>
<p>In terms of handled commands, the payload accepts five possible requests from the C2 server, as described in the table below.</p>
<table style="width: 92.429%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 28.4529%; text-align: center;"><strong>Command Value</strong></td>
<td style="width: 109.917%; text-align: center;"><strong>Command Description</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 28.4529%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0</span></td>
<td style="width: 109.917%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Inject shellcode into </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">explorer.exe</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> or </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">smartscreen.exe</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 28.4529%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">1</span></td>
<td style="width: 109.917%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Execute specified command with </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CMD.exe</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 28.4529%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2</span></td>
<td style="width: 109.917%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Read from local file</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 28.4529%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">3</span></td>
<td style="width: 109.917%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Write data to local file</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 28.4529%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">4</span></td>
<td style="width: 109.917%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Spawn and inject code into </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">WerFault.exe</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a id="post-129063-_gjdgxs"></a><span style="font-size: 8pt; color: #999999;"><em>Table 2. Commands handled by sample.</em></span></p>
<p>Based on the lack of additional commands, it’s likely this is merely a loader for a further sample. As of mid-June, the Dropbox and Graph API credentials are no longer valid, preventing access to any information that was uploaded to either platform.</p>
<h3><a id="post-129063-_x0v1hy7nptua"></a><strong>Technical Analysis of Turkey Campaign</strong></h3>
<p>We identified an additional sample with similar characteristics to other attributed Cloaked Ursa campaigns, which we believe to have been targeting the Turkish Ministry of Foreign Affairs. We did not observe the lure or lures used in this campaign, but we are able to identify the attack chain after the original lure. We assess that the original lure enticed the target to click on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps:// simplesalsamix[.]com/e-yazi.html</span>. The URL is no longer active, but it originally retrieved an HTTP smuggling file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e-yazi.html</span> (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cd4956e4c1a3f7c8c008c4658bb9eba7169aa874c55c12fc748b0ccfe0f4a59a</span>).</p>
<p>The downloaded file is assigned the name <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e-yazi.zip</span>. (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0dd55a234be8e3e07b0eb19f47abe594295889564ce6a9f6e8cc4d3997018839</span>). This sample contains five files.</p>
<p>Once again, a legitimate <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">WinWord.exe</span> binary was found within the archive, named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e-yazi.docx.exe</span>. However, whitespace was added between the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.docx</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.exe</span>, resulting in the file appearing as a document file.</p>
<p>Alongside the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">WinWord.exe</span>, a file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">APPVISVSUBSYSTEMS64.dll</span> (SHA256:</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">60d96d8d3a09f822ded0a3c84194a5d88ed62a979cbb6378545b45b04353bb37</span></p>
<p>) was present once again, as well as a file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">okxi4t.z</span> (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">03959c22265d0b85f6c94ee15ad878bb4f2956a2b0047733edbd8fdc86defc48</span>). This file is similar to the previously mentioned <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ojg2.px</span> in that it contains encrypted shellcode.</p>
<p>On execution of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">WinWord.exe</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">APPVISVSUBSYSTEMS64.dll</span> is sideloaded and (assuming the standard anti-analysis checks were passed) it would open and read the data from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">okxi4t.z</span> before decrypting it and injecting it into the first running process it can.</p>
<p>The injected shellcode shares a number of similarities with code seen in the BMW-related sample, such as the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>General execution flow</li>
<li>Functionality to unhook numerous Windows API calls</li>
<li>Its obfuscation techniques</li>
</ul>
<p>We were also able to confirm that the shellcode contained overlaps with the fourth-stage shellcode dropper loader, shown in Figure 7, as described in the Cloaked Ursa <a href="https://www.gov.pl/web/baza-wiedzy/espionage-campaign-linked-to-russian-intelligence-services" target="_blank" rel="noopener">QUARTERRIG</a> malware report by Military Counterintelligence Service and CERT.PL. The same algorithm and payload structure can be seen within the injected shellcode, as shown in Figure 8, aside from minor differences such as the values of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">magic_const</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hashed_str</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_129126" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129126" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129126" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129063-9-2.png" alt="Image 7 is a screenshot of the shell code structure, and there are options to filter by hashed_str, magic_const, key_a, data_size, key_b, and encrypted_data." width="900" height="434" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129126" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. CERT.PL shellcode structure image. (Source: <a href="https://www.gov.pl/web/baza-wiedzy/espionage-campaign-linked-to-russian-intelligence-services" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Figure 10 of the QUARTERRIG Malware Analysis Report</a>, 2023)</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_129128" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129128" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129128" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129063-10-2.png" alt="Image 8 is a screenshot of the extracted shell code blob. Highlighted in blue in the second row is 57 43 54 4E 46 37 52 58. In the same row is also highlighted WCTNF7RX." width="900" height="535" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129128" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Extracted shellcode blob.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The final payload within this infection chain is somewhat similar to the BMW-linked final payload, in that it leverages both Microsoft Graph API and the Dropbox API for C2 communication. Instead of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Teams_test</span> being the project name, it’s set to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mytestworkapp1</span>. The hard-coded API tokens are also different from the initially analyzed sample.</p>
<p>Similar obfuscation was employed within this sample, including string encryption and control flow obfuscation via abusing the exception handling structures. However, there are no junk functions added to the sample, resulting in a much smaller file size of 498 KB.</p>
<p>It’s worth noting that the string encryption algorithms appear to line up with those seen within the Cloaked Ursa <a href="https://www.gov.pl/web/baza-wiedzy/espionage-campaign-linked-to-russian-intelligence-services" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SNOWYAMBER and QUARTERRIG</a> malware reports by the Military Counterintelligence Service and CERT.PL. Many of the string decryption functions leverage inline assembly keys (as seen in Figure 9), while the rest retrieve keys from the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.rdata</span> directory.</p>
<figure id="attachment_129130" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129130" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129130" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129063-11-2.png" alt="Image 9 is two screenshots of code, one on the left and one on the right. The code in the left box is the first string description function type. The code in the right box is the second string decryption function type." width="900" height="243" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129130" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. First (left) and second (right) string decryption function types.</figcaption></figure>
<p>It’s clear that Cloaked Ursa remains dedicated to identifying legitimate platforms to host their C2 servers, based on their usage of the Microsoft Graph API within these two samples, as well as past reports describing C2 communication via <a href="https://www.gov.pl/web/baza-wiedzy/espionage-campaign-linked-to-russian-intelligence-services" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Notion</a> and <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/cloaked-ursa-online-storage-services-campaigns/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Google Drive</a>.</p>
<p><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Updated July 20, 2023, at 12:43 p.m. PT to change UAC-0029 to UAC-0004. </span></i></p>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 7 June, 2024 at 12:19 PM PDT</span>-->

    <div class="l-container">
            <h2>Related  Resources</h2>
      <div class="blog-slider" id="blogSlider"> 
                    <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/03_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Pictorial representation of a campaign like Contagious Interview. Digital graphic of a glowing globe with network connections and data streams, symbolizing global connectivity and technology advancements." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/03_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/03_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/03_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/03_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/03_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cloaked-ursa-phishing:related-resources:Contagious Interview: DPRK Threat Actors Lure Tech Industry Job Seekers to Install New Variants of BeaverTail and InvisibleFerret Malware:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/north-korean-threat-actors-lure-tech-job-seekers-as-fake-recruiters/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cloaked-ursa-phishing:related-resources:Contagious Interview: DPRK Threat Actors Lure Tech Industry Job Seekers to Install New Variants of BeaverTail and InvisibleFerret Malware">

                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Pisces-NK-A-1920x900-1-786x368.png" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Illustrative image featuring two fish and the Pisces constellation superimposed on a stylized, abstract background with flowing purple waves and a starry night sky." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Pisces-NK-A-1920x900-1-786x368.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Pisces-NK-A-1920x900-1-1493x700.png 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Pisces-NK-A-1920x900-1-768x360.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Pisces-NK-A-1920x900-1-1536x720.png 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/Pisces-NK-A-1920x900-1.png 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cloaked-ursa-phishing:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups:High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-assessment-north-korean-threat-groups-2024/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cloaked-ursa-phishing:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/north-korea/" title="North Korea" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cloaked-ursa-phishing:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups:North Korea">North Korea</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/remote-access-trojan/" title="Remote Access Trojan" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cloaked-ursa-phishing:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups:Remote Access Trojan">Remote Access Trojan</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/finance/" title="Finance" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cloaked-ursa-phishing:related-resources:Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups:Finance">Finance</a>

                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cloaked-ursa-phishing:related-resources:Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cloaked-ursa-phishing:related-resources:Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia">

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			              	 <source media="(max-width:400px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			               	 <source media="(max-width:949px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

<footer class="footer"> 
  <div class="footer-menu">
    <div class="l-container">
      <div class="footer-menu__wrapper">
        <div class="footer-menu-nav__wrapper">
                      <h3 class="footer-menu-nav__title">Products and services</h3>
                                <div class="nav-column__wrapper"> 
            <div class="nav-column">
              													<nav>
					<ul class="footer-menu-nav__list"> 
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item nav-title"> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security"   role="link" title="Network Security Platform" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Network Security Platform">Network Security Platform</a>
						</li>

		</li>
	                <li> 
			<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit-42-threat-vector-podcast/" role="link" title="Podcast" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:social:Podcast">

			</a>
		</li>
</ul>

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.1' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
